nodes.text: Whether and under what conditions the gains from specialization and cooperative production are better realized within an organization (the firm) versus across markets, and what contractual structure explains the firm
Metering problem: efficient organization requires metering input productivity and apportioning rewards, but metering is costly and imperfect which reduces incentives and productivity
Team production defined: production where multiple inputs jointly produce output that is not separable into individual marginal products, making individual contributions hard to observe
High monitoring costs in team production induce shirking because individual private incentives diverge from social marginal costs, so decentralised market exchange may fail to discipline inputs

Residual-claimant monitor solution: appointing a central specialist who is the common contractual party and residual claimant reduces shirking by giving monitoring incentives and unilateral rights to alter membership or contracts
If metering were costless markets could allocate team inputs via entry and replacement, but costly detection and partial attribution of output reductions make market-only replacement insufficient
The firm functions as a specialized, privately owned market institution that collects, collates, and sells information about heterogeneous inputs and their joint productive potential

Necessary conditions for emergence of the classical firm: team-oriented production with costly marginal-product metering, and that observing input behavior is an economical estimator of marginal productivity

Bundle of rights that defines the classical firm owner: (1) residual claim, (2) observe input behavior, (3) be central contracting party, (4) alter individual contracts unilaterally, (5) sell residual status

Granting the residual claimant monitor unilateral renegotiation and membership control economizes on monitoring costs and disciplines team members more effectively than decentralized bilateral contracts

Firms economize on search and informational costs about heterogeneous inputs, enabling internal recombination and promotion rather than continual external hiring, thus supporting conglomeration and divisionalization

Implications for organizational forms: profit-sharing suits small teams and professions where monitoring is hard; partnerships for small self-monitoring teams; corporations use delegated authority, salable shares, and limited liability to manage monitoring and replacement costs; nonprofit/mutual forms display greater shirking because future benefits are not capitalized for monitoring incentives

Evidence/examples: truck loading, lumbermill-cabinetmaker, university perquisites, and historical factory centralization illustrate team production, monitoring costs, and shifts in organizational form

Prediction about asset ownership: inputs whose user-costs or depreciation are easier to observe in use are more likely to be owned rather than rented by the firm; resalable capital equipment tends to be firm-owned

Conclusion: the contractual structure identified (central residual claimant with unilateral renegotiation rights) emerges because it reduces costly metering problems in team production and thus is the economically efficient organizational form under the paper's conditions
